name: title
system_prompt:
You are an assistant tasked with comparing three lists of movies. For each movie, you are given its: title
Your main goal is to assign a diversity score to each list based on the given information.
Use your own judgment to determine what information is relevant when assessing the diversity of the lists. 
You should consider the given title for every movie.

Deliver your descriptions of lists, comparison and choice of the most diverse list in the following JSON format:

{
    "list_A_description": string               # Describe the diversity of the movies in the list A
    "list_B_description": string               # Describe the diversity of the movies in the list B
    "list_C_description": string               # Describe the diversity of the movies in the list C
    "comparison": string,                      # Compare the diversity of the lists.
    "diversity_scores": dict                   # A dictionary assigning a diversity score (0-10) to each list based on its relative diversity. Example: {"A": 5, "B": 2, "C": 10} (where C is the most diverse and B the least).
}

List C:

response.list_A_description: List A shows some diversity in genre, with animation (Big Hero 6), thriller (The Others), crime (Catch Me If You Can), comedy (Meet the Parents), drama (Whiplash), documentary (Super Size Me), action (The Patriot), and workplace comedy (Office Space). However, the range of themes and styles is relatively limited.
response.list_B_description: List B is more focused on action and superhero genres, with The Bourne Identity, The Bourne Supremacy, Guardians of the Galaxy 2, Edge of Tomorrow, Iron Man, and Batman Begins. The inclusion of The Others and Catch Me If You Can adds some variety, but the overall theme is quite consistent.
response.list_C_description: List C is very similar to List B, with a strong emphasis on action and superhero movies.  The addition of The Others and Catch Me If You Can provides a bit more diversity, but the list remains heavily weighted towards a specific genre.
response.comparison: List A exhibits more diversity in genre and themes than Lists B and C. Lists B and C are very similar and primarily consist of action and superhero films, with only a couple of exceptions to break the pattern.  List A includes animation, documentary, and comedy, offering a broader range of cinematic experiences.

TITLE: Inside Out (2015)

TITLE: Bourne Supremacy, The (2004)

TITLE: Help, The (2011)

TITLE: Matrix Revolutions, The (2003)

TITLE: Reservoir Dogs (1992)

TITLE: Friends with Benefits (2011)

TITLE: Pianist, The (2002)

TITLE: Deadpool (2016)


List B:
TITLE: Scanner Darkly, A (2006)

TITLE: Sorcerer's Apprentice, The (2010)

TITLE: Searching for Sugar Man (2012)

TITLE: Frantz (2016)

TITLE: Uncle Sam (1997)

TITLE: Rocky IV (1985)

TITLE: Django Unchained (2012)

TITLE: Botched (2007)


List C:
TITLE: Brave (2012)

TITLE: Thomas Crown Affair, The (1999)

TITLE: Restrepo (2010)

TITLE: A.I. Artificial Intelligence (2001)

TITLE: The Strangers: Prey at Night (2018)

TITLE: Comedy Central Roast of Pamela Anderson (2005)

TITLE: August Rush (2007)

TITLE: Celtic Pride (1996)

response.list_A_description: List A shows some genre diversity with animation (Inside Out), action (Bourne Supremacy, Matrix Revolutions), drama (The Help, The Pianist), crime (Reservoir Dogs), romantic comedy (Friends with Benefits), and superhero (Deadpool). However, it lacks diversity in terms of release years, with most movies being from the 2000s and 2010s.
response.list_B_description: List B has a mix of genres including science fiction (A Scanner Darkly), fantasy (Sorcerer's Apprentice), documentary (Searching for Sugar Man), drama (Frantz), horror (Uncle Sam), sports (Rocky IV), Western (Django Unchained), and reality TV (Botched). The release years are more spread out compared to List A.
response.list_C_description: List C offers a variety of genres: animation (Brave), crime (Thomas Crown Affair), documentary (Restrepo), science fiction (A.I. Artificial Intelligence), horror (The Strangers: Prey at Night), comedy (Comedy Central Roast of Pamela Anderson), drama (August Rush), and sports (Celtic Pride).  The release years are relatively diverse, spanning several decades.
response.comparison: List C exhibits the most significant diversity in terms of genre and release years. List B also demonstrates good diversity, but List A is less diverse, particularly in its concentration of films from a similar time period.

evaluations.prompt:
List A:
TITLE: Matrix, The (1999)

TITLE: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

TITLE: 21 Jump Street (2012)

TITLE: Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring, The (2001)

TITLE: Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers, The (2002)

TITLE: Iron Man 2 (2010)

TITLE: Avatar (2009)

TITLE: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (2010)


List B:
TITLE: Matrix, The (1999)

TITLE: Shrek 2 (2004)

TITLE: Schindler's List (1993)

TITLE: Cast Away (2000)

TITLE: Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse (2018)

TITLE: Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers, The (2002)

TITLE: Departed, The (2006)

TITLE: Mummy Returns, The (2001)


List C:
TITLE: Matrix, The (1999)

TITLE: Kevin James: Never Don't Give Up (2018)

TITLE: Devil's Double, The (2011)

TITLE: Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri (2017)

TITLE: Kevin Hart: What Now? (2016)

TITLE: Sword Art Online Extra Edition (2013)

TITLE: Trap: What Happened to Our Dream of Freedom, The (2007)

TITLE: Bobby Fischer Against the World (2011)

response.list_A_description: List A shows some genre diversity with science fiction (The Matrix, Avatar), fantasy (Lord of the Rings, Harry Potter), and action (21 Jump Street, Iron Man 2). However, it is heavily weighted towards fantasy and action, with a limited representation of other genres.  The inclusion of multiple films within the same franchise (Lord of the Rings, Harry Potter) reduces the overall diversity.
response.list_B_description: List B offers a broader range of genres including science fiction (The Matrix), animation (Shrek 2), drama (Schindler's List, Cast Away, The Departed), action (The Mummy Returns), and superhero (Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse). The inclusion of films from different decades and with varying tones contributes to its diversity.
response.list_C_description: List C demonstrates a diverse range of genres and styles, including stand-up comedy (Kevin James, Kevin Hart), drama (Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri, The Devil's Double, The Trap), and animation (Sword Art Online).  The inclusion of documentaries (Bobby Fischer Against the World) and films from different countries further enhances its diversity. However, the inclusion of multiple stand-up comedy movies reduces the overall diversity.
response.comparison: List B and List C exhibit greater diversity than List A. While List B offers a good mix of genres and tones, List C stands out due to its inclusion of documentaries and films from various cultural backgrounds, despite having some repetition in the comedy genre. List A is less diverse due to its focus on a few similar genres and the repetition of films within the same franchise.

response.list_A_description: List A shows some diversity in genre (action, animation, drama, comedy), but the representation of different themes and time periods could be improved.  There's a mix of animated and live-action films, but the thematic consistency is somewhat limited.
response.list_B_description: List B has a similar genre spread to List A, including action, animation, and drama. However, it features a more consistent thematic focus on adventure and storytelling, with less variation in tone.
response.list_C_description: List C demonstrates a good balance of genres (action, animation, drama, adventure, superhero) and time periods. The inclusion of a more recent animated film and a superhero film enhances its diversity compared to the other lists.
response.comparison: List C exhibits the greatest diversity due to its broader range of genres, animation styles, and time periods represented. Lists A and B show some diversity but are less varied in their thematic and stylistic choices. List A has a slightly more varied genre selection than List B, but List C surpasses both in overall diversity.
